text: testified as follows:
- - - EXAMINATION
Could you state your full name for the record, please?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: David P. Bennett, B-E-N-N-E-T-T.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And whom are you employed by, David?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Elliott Claims, LLC.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: My name is Joseph Blum and I represent Mercedes-Benz in a case that's been brought by Millers Capital insurance. I'm going to ask you a series of questions today.  If at any time you don't understand the question, please let me know and I'll be happy to restate it.  I would ask that you keep all your responses verbal because the court reporter cannot take down our nods or our shrugs.  I would also ask that you try to let me finish my question before you start to speak so that she can take one of us down at a time. Do you understand all that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I understand.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there anything that would prevent you from testifying accurately today?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Not that I'm aware of.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Can you tell me how long you've worked for your current company?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Let me think about it.  I want to say from 2000 is when I hooked up with John Elliott as a subcontractor with John.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are you a subcontractor there now?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what services does he contract with you?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Basically the handling of property claims, generally the larger property claims as opposed to the smaller ones.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And do you evaluate claims for other people or independently?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I have adjusted some independently to my own company, which is B&W Claims, LLC. I also am a subcontractor with Provencher, P-R-O-V-E-N-C-H-E-R, Claims, LLC.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And what types of claims in general are you handling?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: First-party property claims.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are they typically commercial, residential, or both?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: 90% commercial, 10% residential.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long have you worked like as an independent adjuster yourself?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Since '99, 1999.  And then when I first started in the business, which was in '77 or '78.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So in '77 or '78 you started in the claims business, is that what you're saying?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How did you get started?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: My dad was an independent and I was looking to change from working for a title company.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then from '77, '78 all the way to '99, have you operated independently or did you work for other people?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.  From, it's either late '77 to I believe August of '79 I was with a company in Nebraska called State Farmers, not State Farm, that wrote basically farm and residential. And in '79 I went to work for American General Fire and Casualty/Maryland Casualty in Dallas.  Was in the Dallas office four years as first was an auto adjuster, then I picked up liability, then I did comp and did property. And I want to say in '83 I went to Midland Odessa with them as a claims manager of a claims office.  '84 was in San Antonio for a year as a branch supervisor for workers' comp and property.  And '85 went to the regional office as a general adjuster in Houston.  And in '89 was brought up to Baltimore, the home office, as a regional general adjuster for the northeast territory. And then from there to '99, at some point I went inside as a home office property manager, and then the titles changed just to give me more money.  I'm raised time, so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said you worked for a title company before that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Chicago Title Insurance Company back in '76, I think it was '76, '75, '76, in there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And can you tell us what your educational background is?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Graduated high school in '73, did a year at college at Bellevue Junior College, and then went out into the work force.  With American General I completed the Insurance Institute of America three-part course and then the associate in claims course.  And then did the five-year with the -- I'm trying to think of the society -- senior claims loss associate is the final designation I've got. And, of course, all the training for business income, property, storms, whatever.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are those, when you refer to that, are those like company training programs that you're talking about?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: They're national insurance training programs.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And so they were outside of the insurance company with like different associations?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yeah.  The American Educational Institute is a national -- they provide the training or classes or educational material for all divisions of the insurance industry. And then you have the senior claims loss associate, which again is the American Educational Institute, and that's the five-year program on that aspect. And then, of course, you've got the individual training throughout the course that are put on by different entities like the Loss Executives Association, has training seminars. There was Insurance Technical Institute, which was an estimating program.  Then various accounting programs of which I had an accounting background anyway, so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And at some point were you retained to work on or adjust a loss that occurred at the Clemens Cleaning facility here in Lansdale?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What were you asked to do?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Millers' instructions are generally the same on all their claims, is basically I act as the independent adjuster, I evaluate the damages, review the coverages, and see how the damages comply or fall within the different coverages that are available. Determine whether or not we had possible subrogation, just on what the cause may be, and suggest and recommend cause and origin experts to come in.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And you said typically that's what Millers does.  Is that what they did here?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And had you adjusted claims for Millers before this?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Approximately how often?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's a good question.  They generally account probably, I can answer it this way, generally about 40% of my income, yearly income comes from working claims for Millers.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when they hire you, do they pay you per hour, do they pay you per claim?  I mean, how do they compensate you?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I'm on a time and expense basis. And it depends on the complexity of the claim as to whether we charge them a regular adjuster rate or whether we charge them a general adjuster rate.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did you in fact work on the Clemens loss?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What was the first thing you did on that loss?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Received the loss notice, and I believe Alex had an appointment set up for onsite inspection, so I made arrangements to meet at the site with Alex.  And I believe I had already enlisted or I had recommended a cause and origin.  Simply because of the size of it, it's almost standard practice to find out what the origin of the fire is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you actually go to the scene to look at the building?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you meet a representative of the insured there as well?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know who that was, do you remember who that was?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Mr. Clemens.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Randy?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Without reviewing his emails, younger guy, met him on several occasions at the site.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And when you went in to the site, had a determination been made as to whether or not the entire building would be torn down?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: At my initial inspection, the fire marshal was there, and I spoke with him, referenced what they had done and what they were wanting.  And I made recommendations to Alex on site that we needed to bring a structural engineer in to look at the building to make an ascertation of what was rebuildable, what was not rebuildable, and what was structurally damaged and what wasn't.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was in fact a structural engineer retained?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I believe so, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Let me show you a document that we marked earlier today as Hart Exhibit No. 2 and ask you if you have ever seen that before?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's the evaluation report provided by Charles Timbie, structural engineer, on his inspection of the property.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was the purpose of that inspection to determine whether or not the entire structure had to be taken down?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It was to look at the entire structure and determine what was structurally sound and what wasn't.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was your understanding of what his results were?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Standing at the front of the building, basically about two-thirds of it to the right had been determined to be structurally unsound and would need to come down.  My best recollection, it was the last bay plus the interior wall and cement slab over in that area, plus the original cement slab I believe needed some repairs. But exterior walls, roof-wise, probably about two-thirds of the building, all of the exterior finish, all of the roof finish, all the insulation, all the interior drywall. And without looking at a diagram, there was one bay -- I believe there was four bays -- so the one bay where the fire started, the adjoining wall, part of the next wall. And I believe that left the exterior and interior wall of the last bay, again with the slab and framing.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there a determination made at some point to take the whole building down?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That would have been the insured's decision.  I looked at it and valued it as a repairable building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I'm going to mark, if we could, as Bennett Exhibit 1 a handwritten diagram.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: (Hand-drawn diagram marked Bennett Exhibit 1.)
Mr. Bennett, do you recognize this handwritten diagram?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It's not mine, I can tell you that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That was the question, actually, so you got one step ahead of me, that's fine, you can put it aside. At some point were you asked to provide an estimate to repair and/or replace the building?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I proceeded with the repairability estimate based on what the engineer had advised me needed was structurally unsound.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm going to show you a document which we marked as Exhibit 3 this morning and ask you if you can identify this for us?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's my email to Randy, Randy Clemens.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is it that is attached with your email?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's per my email, my preliminary estimate on the rebuild with an ACV replacement cost and actual cash value number.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So can you tell me, is that the cost, is that estimate the cost to repair the building without the entire thing being torn down?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you at any time try to make an estimate of what the actual value of the building was the day before the fire took place?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't believe I did a full valuation on the building, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you know, was anyone else asked to do that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Not that I'm aware of.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So can you tell me -- you mentioned several numbers, I just want to make sure we're all on the same wavelength -- there is various columns on that estimate, one of which is like, I think it's a cost per unit or unit cost?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Tell me what that, your intention of what that means, what does unit cost mean?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's numbers obtained from the Marshall Swift valuation program that I utilize to provide the estimate.  An example would be architectural fees, which generally is a percentage of the estimate, and it comes out to 33,500 for the architectural piece. Everything else represents, another example would be replace vinyl siding insulation, this is after the demolition, $1.52 a square foot, which includes labor and material.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you mentioned a computer program, the Marshall Swift program, just tell us generally what that is?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Marshall Swift is, basically it's a nationwide evaluation program that you can do building valuations on, from residential to any type of commercial.  You can also go in and utilize the unit features for individual building, for framing, for masonry, for insulation, for mechanical, and so forth. It's a recognized valuation program that it can also be used as a rebuild by the insurance industry and most contractors.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so is that estimate that's sitting in front of you like a printout that came directly from that program?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.  This is my -- I input the numbers, I use a program called Simsol, which is an estimating program based off of National Construction Estimator price, plus additional pricing.  And as, which you didn't ask me about, part of what I do is I maintain the database for Simsol and updating and developing pricing.  The majority of that pricing is from National Construction Estimator, some of it utilizes RSMeans, which is another construction program. This type of building I pulled strictly all the numbers from the Marshall Swift and input them into my program, because I'm able to put square footages and room dimensions and then change the pricing to whichever program I'm utilizing.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So I just want to make sure I understand exactly everything you just said. So you went to the Marshall Swift program first?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Marshall Swift, it's actually a manual, it's about longer than legal and about 3 inches thick, and they do provide software that I can go in and pull the pricing out, but it's not really estimating -- it's for valuation and estimating purposes, but then you would have to either write it down or incorporate it, it's not an estimating software.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So is it accurate then that you took some of the data from the Marshall Swift program, and tell me what you did with that data?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: All of the data was taken and all the pricing was taken from the Marshall Swift valuation program in the individual unit breakdowns as opposed to a square foot valuation.  Okay, yes. A little explanation:  Marshall Swift breaks it down.  You can do building valuations on a square foot with additions, or you can go in and actually do a complete rebuild estimate starting with your footers, your foundation, your slabs, whatever type of wall you're dealing with, masonry, your interior finish, your interior framing.  It's providing a detailed estimate. And all I did was take the numbers, the most current numbers from there, and incorporate them into my estimating program so that I could produce an estimate.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So you took the data from the Marshall Swift, both the books and the program, and then you put that information into the estimating software that you used?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So the per unit costs that are listed there, are they from Marshall Swift?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: They're from Marshall Swift.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then after the per unit cost there is an RCV number?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What does RCV stand for in this context?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Replacement cost value.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What does that mean, what do you interpret that to mean?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's basically if something costs $5 a square foot today and you have 200 square feet, that would be roughly, what, $1,000 to replace at today's cost.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So is it taking the unit cost and applying it to what has to be done in this project?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It's taking the unit cost and applying it to the square footage involved.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then after that there is a column, I think it's labeled DEP.  What is that column?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Depreciation.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What does depreciation have to do with in this context?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Under -- every replacement cost policy, you can have a policy that is either on an actual cash value basis or on a replacement cost basis.  And under the loss payment clause of all replacement cost policies, the insured is entitled to the actual cash value of the loss at the time of the loss.  He can then make claim for the replacement cost, as long as he notifies the carrier within 180 days that he's going to make claim under the replacement cost. So the policy was a replacement cost policy, therefore I determined the replacement cost value.  I assessed depreciation, which is a combination of the condition of the building based on my site inspection as well as utilizing relative information provided by the Marshall Swift program as to what depreciation should be, based on the age.  But that all is, I want to say it's subjective, because it's based on the condition of the buildings.  You apply the depreciation to the replacement cost, and that gives you your depreciation amount.  So, in other words, if you have $100,000 loss and you're applying 20% depreciation, your depreciation amount would be $20,000.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And so in the depreciation column, it is the amount of, like the amount of depreciation you took?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And tell me in this context with this loss, was there a percentage that you applied across the board of depreciation?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I would have to go back and look at each individual number.  Within the program itself I'm able to go back and see what was applied.  Generally I'll look at an overall average and then I look at the individual materials.  If the interior finish is in good condition, it can range anywhere from 20 to 35 or 40 percent.  Generally I don't go over 50% unless the building is completely dilapidated. This building was in good condition, so, again, without going into the internal program or doing some calculations here, I don't know if I applied an overall percentage across the board or whether I did it individually by trade or material.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you say go back and look in the program, which program are you referring to?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The estimating program, Simsol that I ultimately put the prices in.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did you use or how did you determine what the original condition of this building was before the fire?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: You can look at a building after a fire and see what the exterior condition is, look in parts of the building where it's undamaged.  And generally the fire in that area just showed a lot of heavy smoke and you can tell whether the building's been maintained or not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was your opinion at that time as to whether or not the building has been maintained?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The building appeared to be in good condition, better than most.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So if you look at the last page, which is the summary of your estimate, the very back.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: All the way back?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Keep going all the way to the end, it's double-sided copy.  That page is an estimate summary for your entire estimate; is that correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And so the actual cash value for the repair came out to like 1.9 million; is that correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Can I --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If he asks the question.
speaker: MR. GOGINENI

text: Go ahead, were you going to explain something?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yeah.  This is the summary details where it's broken down by area group within the estimate, I had about six different groups.  You also find the totals of the estimate on Page 5 of the estimate, which is really the last page of the estimate, it gives you the summary amount there. The next two pages detail trade breakdown, that just breaks out the trade, does not include overhead, profits, and taxes, which is why you will have different numbers on the RCV, depreciation, and ACV. And then you get to the group detail, which when you go into the estimate starting on Page 1, you will find main building right is a grouping, which will go along with main building right here.  This totals each of the individual groups that I had for the building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did you have a set of photographs that you took that went along with your initial review that led to this assessment?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Oh, I probably had anywhere from 40 to 100 overall photos at different times on different inspections.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when I gave you that email, the title, it's entitled that it's the preliminary estimate.  I personally have not seen any other estimates.  Do you know, was there any subsequent estimate to that one?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.  At that point I was in excess of the policy limits, based on these repair numbers, and any adjustments that would have been needed upwards would have still been in excess of the policy limits.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So I take it from your answer then, as far as you recall, there was never a need to go beyond the initial estimate?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what, if anything, did you do in terms of monitoring whether or not the insured rebuilt the building and submitted claims for that rebuilding?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Basically the insured advised me that they were going to just replace the entire building and rebuild it to suit their needs, which is his option. He then had to submit to me all of the expenses that were being incurred so I could review them, see what was covered under the policy, what wasn't covered under the policy, so I could insure that the full 2.3 was expended in the replacement of the building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you say the full 2.3, what do you mean by that number?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The 2.3 million and change was the policy limit.  My estimate was in excess of that.  As long as the insured expended the full 2.3 in excess of the policy limit, over the 2.4 -- my estimate, he would be entitled to recover the depreciation up to the policy limit.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you in fact follow the procedure and monitor the rebuilding and submitting those invoices?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I didn't monitor, but Randy Clemens submitted to me all the invoices.  And then I proceeded and prepared spreadsheets on all the individual invoices from the main general contractor, the emergency services that were provided, as well as some of the subcontractors.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did you do with those spreadsheets?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Provided them to the carrier.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And just tell me generally what they look like, what would one of those spreadsheets look like?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Basically Excel spreadsheets that start over with the general contractor, his totals, and then the breakdown.  And I had found where some subcontractor direct invoices provided to Randy were submitted to me previously, so they had to be deducted, you know, from -- I believe the general contractor was Fenster, I don't recall exactly.  But the GC was paying the subs direct, and Randy had actually submitted me some of the sub bids directly.  So they were duplicated within my spreadsheets and I made sure that there was no duplications, and that certain items that would not have been covered under the policy were not included within the totals.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you have any examples of what those would be that would not have been covered?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Excavation, land filling, striping of the parking lot, things like along those lines that were normally excluded under the policy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what else, if anything, did you do in the adjustment of this loss?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Worked with Randy on his loss of income claim.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And tell me what was the loss of income claim?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The amount?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: No.  What was the basis of the loss of income?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Clemens, the dry cleaning operations, occupied I want to say probably 60% of the building, and I believe there was one other tenant-occupied area.  So the lease for the one tenant was obtained in order to ascertain the rent that was being charged by the dry cleaning.  They provided financial records showing what was being internally paid for the rent space, as well as the CAM adjustments, which would have been the charges for prorated taxes based on the amount of square footage being occupied by the tenant, maintenance, things like that that fall within the CAM. So you spread that out over the time period of 12 months along with the CAM adjustments, which the history was on the full taxes, and the taxes were actually dropped after the fire, so we had to wait for the revised or new tax bill. And so those amounts were adjusted and that was determined to be the loss of income under the terms of the policy for the 12 months, and then there was a 60-day extension beyond that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And what was your involvement, did you verify all that or how did you -- what was your personal part in taking care of that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Oh, I had the lease and verified the payments and verified the tax bills and then put together the spreadsheets.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was that a spreadsheet that, again, you provided to the insurance company?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I just want to make sure I understand.  So did the insurance company reimburse the insured for the full payment of the lease, the full amount of the lease?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It would have been per my spreadsheet calculation.  As I said, the rental portion pretty much stayed the same for the 12 months, that's set.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The CAM was adjusted according to what the new taxes were, which reflected a drop over the previous year, so obviously the taxes were dropped by the local borough or officials once the building was destroyed or damaged. So the loss of income included the lease amounts from the dry cleaners as well as the one tenant -- and I'm going from memory -- along with the CAM because that was paid in addition to the base lease amount.  And that amount was figured for 12 months.  And then for the additional 60 days, I believe there was a 35% calculation.  The 60 days under the policy is provided from when the building is substantially built or the stock is replenished so that you can reopen.  It gives the insured an additional 60 days to get back up to full. Clemens Dry Cleaners had basically occupied about, I want to say 65%, and there was still 10% undone, I'd have to look at my reports.  But they occupied a percentage, there was a percentage still being done.  So in order to conclude the claim for the additional 60 days, it was agreed on a 35% loss for those next two months.  And then that closed down the claim.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Just so I understand what your answer is, that 35% you quoted, or if it's 30, whichever it was, was a number that you negotiated with Clemens?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Basically it's, you take what they're losing, and if they were losing 10,000 a month in leases and the percentage was 30 or 35, 30% of 10,000 would have been $3,000 for each of the 60-day period.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm just trying to get to, how did you get to that percentage?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I looked at what percentage of the building they were occupying and using to run their operations, the percentage, approximate percentage of the building that was yet to be completed, so, and what would have been available for rent had they rebuilt the same building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And just so I'm clear, in the way this coverage was written, there was no attempt by the insurance company to deduct from the income amount that was reimbursed the amount of money that was saved by them by not operating the building?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.  Each of the tenants, the dry cleaning was separate from the owner, okay? So the tenants were responsible for the utilities, as I remember correctly.  So the only savings to the building would have been any reduction in property taxes and so forth. Had the building been vacant, he would have incurred additional utility expenses.  So in my estimation there was no reduction in expenses other than the property taxes had been reduced.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: And there was no management company involved, payments were made direct to the named insured on the building.  So therefore there was no management fee to reduce the amount of the rent spot.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Was there anything else that you recall doing in the adjustment of the loss for this fire?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Other than, I met with the engineers, met with the cause and origin people, met with the fire marshal, met with the insured on various occasions, and did several inspections and followup inspections on the rebuild, so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And other than hiring the experts for the cause and origin investigation, what other involvement did you have, if any, in that investigation?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: As far as trying to make a determination of the cause?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: None.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you present for any of the inspections that were done by the cause and origin investigators?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The initial inspection, I believe he was there the very first day.  And then I was there subsequently when I believe representatives from Mercedes were there. There were several people, I had signed in on the log just to basically look at what they were doing, but then to do what I needed to do on the building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And when the Mercedes people were there, did you have any discussion with them at all?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Not that I recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you ever had any discussion with any representatives of Mercedes --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let me finish my question. -- about the fire?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Not that I recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you been present for any inspections of the Mercedes vehicle that was involved in the fire?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: After it was removed?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Correct.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you participated in any meetings where there were representatives of various insurance companies who got together to discuss this loss?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And other than Mr. Timbie, were there any other engineers that you hired on behalf or recommended to Millers on their behalf about this investigation?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't recall any others being recommended by me.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is there anything else you recall doing in the adjustment of this loss?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't recall anything else, no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Give me one second, I have a couple documents I'm going to mark and we'll be done. I'm going to mark this as Bennett 2.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: (Email, 10/3/17, to Randy Clemens from Bennett marked Bennett Exhibit 2.)
Mr. Bennett, I'm showing you a document which was produced by Millers, and ask you if you recognize what this document is?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It's an email from me to Randy Clemens.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And I assume from the look of it that someone at the insurance copy, Alex Hart, was also copied; correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Alex Hart with the insurance company, and I don't recognize the Clugstonk@univest.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was the purpose of this email?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: This was in reference to a spreadsheet that I put together some time around October 2017, where I highlighted items and basically summarized what the spreadsheet was reflecting regarding review of invoices that had been submitted by Randy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you know, was this October 3, 2017, at a point where you were basically attempting to close out the payments that were being made by the insurance company?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: This was where we were -- I was reviewing invoices to verify expenditures that would have been in excess of the ACV payment that was made to ascertain how much additional Randy would be entitled to under the policy up to the policy limit.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you know when those issues were resolved in terms of like the final payments that were made?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I believe with my final report, I believe my final report was some time in January of 2018.  And it may have been resolved between this October email and that period of time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Tell me what that final report would have looked like, just generally?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Pardon?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What would your final report have looked like?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I know it was incorrectly labeled as the second report, but it was dated January and it reflected, I believe, the final additional payment that would be needed under the building to bring out the full payment on the building.  And I may have also concluded the rents at the same time.  I don't recall without looking at the report.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I have no further questions.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: - - - EXAMINATION
Hi, just briefly a few questions. During your work in this loss did you ever talk to any representative or individual from Bergey's Leasing or the company that leased the vehicle?
speaker: MR. GARBARINO

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did Mr. Clemens ever tell you why they wanted to tear the building down?
speaker: MR. GARBARINO

text: I recall discussions regarding it would be better to, at this time, with this extended damage, and with the dry cleaning business needing additional space to move the dry cleaning operations into the building and have it renovated to more specifically fit the dry cleaning business as opposed to leasing out to individual tenants.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And I know you said that generally sometimes you will see if there's any subrogation issues when you get hired by Millers.  Do you remember if you made any recommendations about subrogation in regards to this loss?
speaker: MR. GARBARINO

text: I can give you in general how that works.  I don't recall specifically on this particular claim.  When the origin and cause gives me have an approximate or gives me a verbal as to the cause, and it appears it may be something that needs further investigation for potential subrogation, then I would recommend passing along that information to the carrier. On this particular case I believe everybody, the cause and origin was reporting direct to a counsel that had been enlisted, a subrogation counsel, which is almost standard practice on any loss of any specific size, just to get subrogation counsel involved early on to make sure that all steps that he needs are covered.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's all the questions I have.  Thank you.
speaker: MR. GARBARINO

text: No questions.
speaker: MR. SLATTERY
